transcript.page:
fol.100v
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.
2 Junij
1591
. M
r
Bodeley from
e Haghe to my L./
2 June 91
fol.99r
May it please yo
r
good L. because in
yesterdaies letter, wherein I writte to yo
r
L.
of
e taking of
Deventer,
I could specifie but
litle of
e circumstance and meanes, I have
therfore sent yo
w
e translated copies out of
Dutche of
e letters of advertisment, w
ch
came
sins from
e campe, to
e
general states
. Withall
because
e agreement was one both with De-
venter and
Zutphen,
I have sent yo
w
a copie
of
e said agreement,
and therew
t
take my
humble leave. From
e Hage. June 2
1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
I have as yet no letter from any English at
the Campe, for whiche I can not report what
was done by them in speciall. But many say
heere of
e common people, that their couragious
comming to
e assault (where it is also given
out, that they caried an enseigne from
e walles)
appalled the Enemie exceedingly, and was
e
principal cause of their yelding upon it.
